acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists
acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "gas" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its dust/mist is not expected.

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Based on the rat LC50 (inhalation of gas) value of 16.2ppm (4 hours).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_vapor.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "gas" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its vapour is not expected.

carcinogenicity.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is classified as Category 1 (as ARSENIC AND ARSENIC COMPOUNDS) by IARC (1987) and Category K (as Arsenic Compounds, Inorganic) by NTP (2005).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to gas substances are not available

explosives.rationale: Classified as "gas" according to GHS definition

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases
flammable_gases.rationale: Based on the description in ICSC (2004): the lower explosion limit is 4.5vol%. Classified into Division 2.1 (UN#2188) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "gas" according to GHS definition

flammable_solids.rationale: Classified as "gas" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.hazard_statement: Contains gas under pressure; may explode if heated
gases_under_pressure.rationale: The boiling point is -62degC (ICSC (2004)) and the critical temperature is 100degC (HSDB (2006)), i.e., liquefied gas. Classified into Division 2.1 and Division 2.3 (UN#2188) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods).

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale:
No data available
As for the health hazards, refer to "ID1075, Sodium Arsenate, CAS: 13464-38-5," "ID1088, Sodium Arsenite, CAS: 7784-46-5," "ID54, Arsenic, CAS: 7440-38-2" and "ID55, Diarsenic Trioxide (Arsenious Acid), CAS: 1327-53-3."

organic_peroxides.rationale: Classified as "gas" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified into Division 2.1 and Division 2.3 (UN#2188) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "gas" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Classified as "gas" according to GHS definition

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "gas" according to GHS definition

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Classified as "gas" according to GHS definition

reproductive_toxicity.rationale:
No data available
As for the health hazards, refer to "ID1075, Sodium Arsenate, CAS: 13464-38-5," "ID1088, Sodium Arsenite, CAS: 7784-46-5," "ID54, Arsenic, CAS: 7440-38-2" and "ID55, Diarsenic Trioxide (Arsenious Acid), CAS: 1327-53-3."

self_heating_substances.rationale: Classified as "gas" according to GHS definition

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Classified as "gas" according to GHS definition

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Classified as "gas" according to GHS definition

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (blood system)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "a decrease in hemoglobin level to 32g/L and basophilic stippling (in red blood cells)" (IARC 84 (2004)), and the evidence from animal studies including "anemia (decreased hemoglobin/hematocrit/RBC)" (CICAD 47 (2002)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.classification: Category 1 (central nervous system, blood system, cardiovascular system, respiratory system, liver, kidney)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: Causes damage to organs (central nervous system, blood system, cardiovascular system, respiratory system, liver, kidney)
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the human evidence: "clinical symptoms include transient hemolytic anemia, nausea, headache, anemia, decreased hemoglobin levels, erythema of the skin, jaundice, hemoglobinuria and shock" (IARC 84 (2004)), "pulmonary edema and acute circulatory disorder," "hepatitis on the 20th day after the acute hemolysis" (CICAD 47 (2002)), "hemolysis and nephropathy" (ACGIH (7th, 2001)), and the evidence from animal studies including "a 10.5% reduction in hematocrit levels observed in the 26ppm dose group" (CICAD 47 (2002)). The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1.
